lead_paragraph: BENDER--John C. John C. Bender passed away in New York City on April 3, 2016, after a brief illness. He was a generous and loving husband and father, an avid traveler to destinations such as Antarctica, the Galapagos, and Africa, and an overall lover of life. He was born on May 17, 1940 in Queens, New York. He attended Flushing High School and received an engineering degree from Northeastern University. He studied law at night while working as an engineer, earning a J.D. and LL.M. from New York University Law School, where he also served as the Assistant Director of the New York University Center for International Studies. He had a varied and accomplished legal career in both the private and public sectors. He worked in private practice at the law firms of Poletti Freidin and Marshall Bratter, and as vice president and general counsel at News America Publishing Inc., Simon and Schuster, and Macmillan Publishing Inc. His work in the public sector included positions as chairman of the Trust for Cultural Resources for the City of New York, general counsel of the New York State Financial Control Board for the City of New York, and special counsel of the Moreland Act Commission on Nursing Homes. He was an active board member of a number of not- for-profit organizations including the Village Nursing Home, Inc., the Mary McDowell Center for Learning, the Friends of the New York City Housing Authority Symphony Orchestra, the Oakwood Friends School, and most recently the Harlem Chamber Players. He will be remembered by his family and friends for his quick wit, hearty laugh, and expressive eyebrows! He was pre-deceased by his parents, John and Cecelia, and his sister Joan. He is survived by his wife Helen, daughter Marianna, brother-in-law Charlie, niece Karen, nephew Steve, and dog Tucker. 1/3
